subject: Re: JUnit ClassCastException problem
msgSnippet: Yes, JUnit uses a custom class loader.  Try the fix for a similiar problem: http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm#ClassNotFoundException Erik Meade

Yes, JUnit uses a custom class loader.  Try the fix for a similiar 
problem:

http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm#ClassNotFoundException

Erik Meade
http://junit.org
emeade@...


--- In junit@y..., randy.carey@l... wrote:
> 
> One of the guys in our team has a class casting problem that shows 
up only
> when run from within a TestCase.
> 
> In the code, the object being cast prints out its class name and 
this is
> the same as the class to which we are casting.  The test code and 
the class
> where the cast is made both exist in a default package.
> 
> // example code:
>     my.Type a = Factory.instance( );
>    // we query on "a" and it prints out its type as "my.Type", and 
the
> value is not null.
>     my.Type b = (my.Type) a;   // this line throws a class cast 
exception
> 
> I'm guessing that the JUnit framework launches its own class loader 
and
> it's getting confused with some code existing in a default package.
> 
> Does anyone have an idea of what is going on?  Does all code need 
to be
> found in a named package?
